questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard?

discussion.content: The purpose of the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard (FHS) is to provide a consistent and unified way of organizing the file system on Linux and other Unix-like operating systems. It defines the structure and location of files and directories on the system, specifying where different types of files should be located and how they should be named, as well as common directories and files that should be present in every compliant system. The FHS is important for software developers and system administrators to ensure that their software and systems are compatible with the wider Unix ecosystem.

questions.question_text: Instead of supplying an explicit device in /etc/fstab for mounting, what other options may be used to identify the intended partition? (Choose TWO correct answers.)

comments.content:
The correct answers are C and E.

C. LABEL - this allows the administrator to assign a unique label to a file system and use this label in /etc/fstab to refer to the file system.

E. UUID - this allows the administrator to use a unique identifier for the file system, which is based on the file system's Universally Unique Identifier (UUID), to mount the file system in /etc/fstab.

The common reason for the error message "umount: /mnt: device is busy" is that a user has a file open in the /mnt directory, which prevents the device from being unmounted. Other possible reasons could include processes running on the device, active network connections or open file handles to files on the device.

choices.B: A user has a file open in the /mnt directory.
choices.A: The kernel has not finished flushing disk writes to the mounted device.
choices.E: The kernel thinks that a process is about to open a file in /mnt for reading.
choices.D: The files in /mnt have been scanned and added to the locate database.
choices.C: Another file system still contains a symlink to a file inside /mnt.

questions.question_text:
After running the command umount /mnt, the following error message is displayed: umount: /mnt: device is busy.
What is a common reason for this message?

discussion.content: The correct answer is D. The command mount -a mounts all filesystems listed in the /etc/fstab file which have the option "auto" set. It is typically used during system boot to mount all specified filesystems automatically.

choices.D: It mounts all filesystems listed in /etc/fstab which have the option auto set.
choices.A: It mounts all available filesystems onto the current directory.
choices.E: It mounts all filesystems listed in /etc/fstab which have the option noauto set.
choices.C: It mounts all user mountable filesystems for the current user.
